document.docTitle: Allotanaupodus williamsi Zhang & Fan, 2007, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Allotanaupodidae, a new family of early derivative Parasitengona (Acari: Prostigmata)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Allotanaupodidae, a new family of early derivative Parasitengona (Acari: Prostigmata)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Prodorsum (
Fig. 4
A ). About half as long ( 410 Âµm) as wide ( 750 Âµm). Prodorsal plate longer ( 410 Âµm) than wide ( 350 Âµm), not extending beyond anterior edge of propodosoma, with 11â€“12 pairs of lanceolate setae on each side, anteriormost pair 106â€“107 Âµm long. Crista metopica linear, rod-like, 275â€“300 Âµm long, widest anteriorly, ca 20â€“23 Âµm. 2â€“3 pairs of lanceolate setae posterolateral to prodorsal plate (two of them laterad of eyes), each on a platelet; these setae ca 75 Âµm long. Lateral prodorsal plate absent. Eye plates
85â€“ 90
x 54â€“55 Âµm, diameter 31â€“33 Âµm for anterior eyes and 26â€“28 Âµm for posterior eyes.
Hysterosomal dorsum . Hysterosoma with some indication of segmentation, each with large lateral plates bearing several to numerous setae; C and D separated by an evident furrow.
C row with a pair of sublateral plates each bearing 10â€“12 setae; other setae each on a platelet; a few of these lateral to sublateral plates.
D row with a pair of sublateral plates each bearing 3â€“5 pairs of setae; lateral and medial setae of the row each on a platelet, except a pair of submedian plates, each bearing two setae.
E row with a pair of sublateral plate each bearing 4â€“5 setae; lateral and medial setae each on a platelet.

F row with a pair of sublateral plate each bearing 7â€“9 setae; other setae of this row each on a platelet, except a pair of submedian plates near posterior margin of this row, each bearing two setae.
H row with two pairs of plates each bearing 5â€“6 pairs of setae; a few lateral and medial setae each on a platelet.
PS row with a pair of terminal plates each bearing several pairs of setae.

Idiosomal venter (
Fig. 2
). Intercoxal area of leg I normally with 6 pairs of short setae (< 50 Âµm long; posterolateral pair
1 a
the longest, over 100 long); intercoxal area of leg II with about 7 pairs of setae. Intercoxal area of leg III with numerous pairs of setae and that of leg IV with numerous setae not separable from those anterior to genital area. Between coxa II and coxa III on each side a plate of numerous setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult female). Dorsal view of idiosoma.

FIGURE 2.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult female). Ventral view of idiosoma.

subSubSection.paragraph: Coxal I with 22â€“26 setae. Coxa II with 17â€“20 setae. Coxa III with 16â€“18 setae. Coxa IV with 16â€“19 setae. Opisthoventer with numerous short setiform setae similar to coxal setae. Genital opening 230â€“245 Âµm long. A pair of central valves each bearing 7â€“9 setae (ca 50 Âµm long). A pair of lateral valves each bearing 11 setae of similar size. Eugenital setae absent. Anal opening 168â€“185 Âµm long, its valves each with three pairs of setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult female). A, chelicerae; B, subcapitulum; C, palp; D, palpal tarsus.

FIGURE 4.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult female). A, prodorsal shield; B, genital opening; C, anal opening; D, dorsal idiosomal seta; E, ventral idiosomal seta.

paragraph.bibRef:
Leg I
1330â€“1333
Âµm. Trochanter I
with numerous setulose setae. Basifemur I 155â€“190 Âµm, Telofemur I 208â€“225 Âµm. Genu I 250â€“258 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, three solenidia and one microseta ( 35 Âµm long). Tibia I 280 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae and solenidia, and one microseta
(
44
Âµm long).

subSubSection.paragraph: Tarsus I more than twice as long ( 335â€“350 Âµm) as wide ( 150 Âµm), with many setulose setae and solenidia; famulus ca. 20 Âµm long.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult female). A, leg I; B, leg II; C, leg III; D, leg IV; E, detail view of tarsus I.

subSubSection.paragraph: Leg II 830â€“890 Âµm. Trochanter II with 12â€“13 setae. Basifemur II 140 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae. Telofemur II 136 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and a distal solenidion. Genu II 146 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, one solenidion and one microseta ( 30 Âµm long). Tibia II 157 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae and two solenidia. Tarsus II 235 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, 3 dorsal solenidia, one famulus ( 13 Âµm long) and two distal eupathidia.

Leg III 960â€“985 Âµm. Trochanter III with 13â€“17 setae. Basifemur III 140 Âµm long with numerous setae. Telofemur III 136 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and a distal solenidion. Genu III 164 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and three solenidia. Tibia III 195 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and two solenida. Tarsus III 233 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae and three solenidia.

paragraph.bibRef:
Leg IV
1280â€“1350 Âµm. Trochanter IV with
17â€“22
setae . Basifemur IV
200
Âµm long with numerous setae. Telofemur IV 176 Âµm long with numerous setae and 1 distal solenidion ( 45 Âµm long). Genu IV 230 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and 4 solenidia. Tibia IV 306 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and four solenidia, of which the two distal ones are twice as long as others. Tarsus IV 282 Âµm long with many setulose setae and three solenidia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 3
). Subcapitulum with two pairs of adoral setae and one pair of subcapitular setae (
Fig. 3
B). Adoral setae: or 1 37â€“40 Âµm, or 2 35â€“40 Âµm. Subcapitular setae 70 Âµm.

Cheliceral base 225 Âµm long, cheliceral blade 65 Âµm long (
Fig. 3
A).

Palp 488â€“570 Âµm long (
Fig. 3
C). Palptrochanter with two setae, 75 and 100 Âµm long, respectively. Palpfemur with 11 setae. Palpgenu with 12â€“15 setae. Palptibia with 14 nude setae, a strong terminal seta (i.e. tibial claw, 33 Âµm long) and a ventral enlarged seta ( 27 Âµm long) near base of tibial claw, ratio of tibial length excluding tibial claw and maximum tibial width 2.3â€“2.5 . Palptarsus with a basal solenidion ( 20 Âµm long), two nude setiform setae, and six terminal eupathidia ( 18â€“21 Âµm long).

Prodorsum. About half as long ( 385 Âµm) as wide ( 725 Âµm). Prodorsal plate longer ( 375 Âµm) than wide ( 275 Âµm), not reaching anterior end of propodosoma, with 12â€“14 pairs of lanceolate setae on each side, anteriormost pair 100â€“125 Âµm long (
Fig. 9
A). Crista metopica linear, rodâ€“like, 275â€“325 Âµm long, widest anteriorly, ca 15â€“22 Âµm. 3â€“9 pairs of lanceolate setae posterolateral to prodorsal plate (one or two of them laterad of eyes), each on a platelet, ca 75â€“80 Âµm long. Prodorsal lateral plates absent. Eye plates
75â€“ 95
x 50â€“60 Âµm, diameter 32â€“37 Âµm for anterior eyes and 25â€“30 for posterior eyes.
Hysterosomal dorsum . Hysterosoma with traces of segmentation, each with large lateral plates bearing several to numerous setae, division between C and D a clearly evident furrow.
C row with a pair of sublateral plates each bearing 7 setae; other setae each on a platelet.
D row with a pair of sublateral plates each bearing 3â€“5 pairs of setae; lateral and medial setae each on a platelet (except a single medial pair together on one plate).
E row with a pair of sublateral plates each bearing 5â€“7 setae, lateral and medial setae each on a platelet.
F row with a pair of sublateral plate each bearing 8â€“9 pairs of setae, lateral and medial setae each on a platelet.
H segment with two pairs of plates each bearing 5â€“6 pairs of setae; a few other setae each on a platelet.
PS segment with a pair of terminal plates each bearing several pairs of setae.

Idiosomal venter (
Fig. 7
). Intercoxal area of leg I with 9â€“10 pairs of short setae (< 50 Âµm long; posterolateral pair the longest,
1 a
over 100 Âµm long), intercoxal area of leg II with 5â€“9 pairs of setae. Intercoxal area of leg III with numerous pairs of setae and that of leg IV with numerous setae not separable from those anterior to genital area. Coxal I with 22â€“26 setae. Coxa II with 17â€“22 setae. Coxa III with 16â€“20 setae. Coxa IV with 17â€“24 setae. Opisthoventer with numerous short setiform setae similar to coxal setae. Genital opening 190â€“ 250 Âµm. A pair of central valves each bearing 7â€“9 setae. A pair of lateral valves each bearing 7â€“15 setae of similar size. With three or five pairs of eugenital setae, all nude, setiform. Anal opening 145â€“195 Âµm long, its valves each with 1â€“4 pairs of setae.

paragraph.bibRef:
Leg I
1075â€“1445
Âµm. Trochanter I with 12â€“15 setae. Basifemur I 140â€“175 Âµm. Telofemur I 185â€“215 Âµm. Genu I 190â€“265 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, two solenidia and a microseta ( 32 Âµm long). Tibia I 200â€“350 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and solenidia, and one microseta
(
35
Âµm long). Tarsus I more than twice as long ( 255â€“360 Âµm) as wide ( 95â€“163 Âµm), with many setulose setae and solenidia; famulus peglike, 3 Âµm long.

FIGURE 6.
Allotanaupodus williamsi

subSubSection.paragraph: Leg II 760â€“830 Âµm. Trochanter II with 9â€“15 setae. Basifemur II 130 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae. Telofemur II 130 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and a distal solenidion. Genu II 135 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, one solenidion and one microseta ( 22 Âµm long). Tibia II 143 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae and two solenidia. Tarsus II 205 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae, five dorsal solenidia, one famulus ( 15 Âµm long) and two distal eupathidia.

FIGURE 7.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult male). Ventral view of idiosoma.

FIGURE 8.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult male). A, chelicerae; B, subcapitulum; C, palp; D, palpal tarsus; E, anal opening.

subSubSection.paragraph: Leg III 900â€“1085 Âµm. Trochanter III with 16â€“20 setae. Basifemur III 130 Âµm long with numerous setae. Telofemur III 130 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and a distal solenidion. Genu III 160 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and three solenidia. Tibia III 180 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and two solenida. Tarsus III 230 Âµm long, with numerous setulose setae and two solenidia.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult male). A, prodorsal shield; B, genital opening; C, eugenital structure; D, dorsal idiosomal seta; E, ventral idiosomal seta.

paragraph.bibRef:
Leg IV
1200â€“1375
Âµm. Trochanter IV
with 19â€“22 setae. Basifemur IV 175 Âµm long with numerous setae. Telofemur IV 160 Âµm long with numerous setae and 1 distal solenidion ( 48 Âµm long). Genu IV 220 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and 4 solenidia. Tibia IV 295 Âµm long with numerous setulose setae and four solenidia, of which two distal ones are twice as long as others. Tarsus IV 270 Âµm long with many setulose setae and one solenidion
(
30
Âµm long).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Allotanaupodus williamsi
sp. n.
(adult male). A, leg I; B, leg II; C, leg III; D, leg IV; E, detail view of tarsus I.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 8
). Subcapitulum with two pairs of large adoral setae (in addition, one minute pair also seen in some specimens) and one pair of subcapitular setae (in the holotype , the left side has abnormally three setae). Adoral setae: or 1 35 Âµm, or 2 35 Âµm.

Cheliceral base 208â€“232 Âµm long, cheliceral blade 65â€“70 Âµm long (
Fig. 8
A).

Palp 490â€“597 Âµm long (
Fig. 8
C). Palptrochanter with two setae, 75 and 100 Âµm long. Palpfemur with 9â€“ 11 setae. Palpgenu with 13â€“15 setae. Palptibia with 14â€“18 nude setae, a strong terminal seta (i.e. tibial claw, 35 Âµm long) and a ventral enlarged seta ( 25 Âµm) near base of tibial claw. Ratio of tibial length excluding tibial claw to maximum width 2.2â€“2.8 . Palptarsus with a basal solenidion ( 15 Âµm long), two nude setiform setae, and six terminal eupathidia ( 22 Âµm long).
Named after the collector, D. Williams.

Holotype female New Zealand , AK: Kawau I. (
36.42 Â°S
,
174.85 Â°E
),
15 June to 10 August 1992
, Malaise trap, D. Williams. Allotype male, one paratype one and two paratype females, same data. Four paratype males, same data except collected during
13 October to 12 November 1992
.
The feeding habit of this species is unknown. All nine specimens were caught in Malaise traps; presumably they are free-living predators of small arthropods in the soil.

This species has the largest series of specimens and multiple males and females are represented. Some variation among specimens was observed in the female holotype , the C row has a median plate with three setae, whereas the other two specimens have all median setae of the C row on a single small platelet.
